intro: Bupleurum isphairamicum, commonly known as the narrow-leaved bellflower, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes plants like carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and thrives in temperate climates. Its flowering period occurs in the summer months, and it is often found in alpine meadows. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endangered species in many areas.
